title: Sticking to The MIND Diet Could Reduce Your Risk of Developing Dementia - ScienceAlert
summary:
Sticking to The MIND Diet Could Reduce Your Risk of Developing Dementia

Publication Date: Unknown Source: Unknown

The food you eat could either protect you from dementia or put you at higher risk, according to several studies. Two new papers suggest that reducing gut inflammation through diet may help lower dementia risk.

  • A diet high in inflammatory foods increases dementia risk by 84%.
  • The MIND diet, which includes foods that boost antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities, is linked to slower cognitive decline.
  • The research involved over 5,200 older adults, revealing differences in dietary adherence among racial groups.
"Although these promising findings need to be replicated and further validated, our results suggest that diets that correlate with low dietary inflammatory index scores may prevent late-life dementia."

It’s a simple step everyone can take towards lowering their dementia risk.
newTitle: Sticking to The MIND Diet Could Reduce Your Risk of Developing Dementia

title: ​Airborne microplastic can lead to lung and colon cancers, says study - The Times of India
summary:
Airborne Microplastics Linked to Lung and Colon Cancers

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Unknown

This article discusses a recent study which indicates that airborne microplastics can significantly contribute to the development of lung and colon cancers in humans.

  • The study highlights the increasing prevalence of microplastics in the environment.
  • Evidence shows a correlation between microplastic exposure and cancer risk.
  • The research stresses the need for further investigation into the health impacts of microplastics.
“The pervasive presence of microplastics in our air and their potential health effects should be a serious concern for public health.”

This study underscores the urgent need for actions to mitigate microplastic pollution and protect public health.
newTitle: Airborne Microplastics Linked to Lung and Colon Cancers

title: New Research Shows Eating the Occasional Sweet Treat Is Better for Your Heart Than No Sugar at All - Health.com
summary:
New Research Shows Eating the Occasional Sweet Treat Is Better for Your Heart Than No Sugar at All

Publication Date: December 8, 2023 | Source: Frontiers in Public Health

Eating a small amount of sugar from time to time might be better for your heart than completely eliminating it, according to a new study.

  • The study reports that the impact of added sugar on heart health varies by the type of sugar consumed.
  • Those consuming sugar from pastries and natural toppings like honey had better heart health outcomes than those consuming sugar-sweetened beverages.
  • Moderate sugar intake around 7.5% of daily energy intake is associated with the best cardiovascular outcomes.
  • The average American's sugar intake is significantly higher than the range linked to optimal cardiovascular health.
“The study reinforces that sugar doesn’t have to be eliminated entirely. It’s about moderation, awareness, and balance.” – Kailey Ogilvie, MS, RDN

Overall, while some sugar can be beneficial, it is crucial to consume it in moderation and focus on healthy eating patterns.
newTitle: New Research Shows Eating the Occasional Sweet Treat Is Better for Your Heart Than No Sugar at All

title: Bavarian Nordic Must Prioritize Africa in Localized Mpox Vaccine Production - AIDS Healthcare Foundation
summary:
Bavarian Nordic Must Prioritize Africa in Localized Mpox Vaccine Production

Publication Date: August 2024 Source: AIDS Healthcare Foundation

The AIDS Healthcare Foundation (AHF) calls on Bavarian Nordic to share technology for mpox vaccine production with African manufacturers and to lower vaccine costs for lower-income countries, particularly as the Democratic Republic of the Congo and surrounding areas grapple with significant mpox outbreaks.

  • AHF urges Bavarian Nordic to prioritize Africa in its vaccine distribution strategy.
  • Public Citizen supports the call for equitable access to vaccines through technology sharing.
  • Children are particularly vulnerable, with significant case and fatality rates reported in the DRC.
  • The need for affordable mpox vaccines is critical given historical inequities with COVID-19 vaccine distribution.
“With Africa still bearing the brunt of the mpox outbreak, Bavarian Nordic must prioritize Africa with lower costs, technology transfer, and regional manufacturing...” - Daniel Reijer, AHF Europe Bureau Chief

The call for action emphasizes the importance of equitable vaccine access to prevent further crisis in Africa amidst the ongoing mpox outbreak.
newTitle: Bavarian Nordic Urged to Focus on Africa for Mpox Vaccine Production

title: CDC Confirms First US Case of Severe Bird Flu - WIRED
summary:
CDC Confirms First Severe Bird Flu Case in the US

Publication Date: December 18, 2024

Source: Wired

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has confirmed the first severe case of avian influenza caused by the H5N1 virus in the United States, marking a concerning shift in the pattern of human infections.

  • The patient, hospitalized in Louisiana, had exposure to sick birds in backyard flocks.
  • This case is the first severe illness linked to H5N1 in the US, previously seen only in mild cases.
  • Since April, 61 human cases of bird flu were reported in the US, all mild until now.
  • The H5N1 virus has significant historical associations with severe illness and high mortality rates in other countries.
  • No person-to-person transmission of H5N1 has been detected, and the public health risk remains low.
“While an investigation into the source of this infection in Louisiana is ongoing, it is believed that the patient that was reported by Louisiana had exposure to sick or dead birds on their property.” – Demetre Daskalakis, CDC

Although this case raises concerns, the CDC reassures that the immediate risk to public health is still regarded as low, urging caution for individuals in contact with infected animals.
newTitle: CDC Confirms First Severe Bird Flu Case in the US

title: US Reports First Severe Infection Of Bird Flu In A Human - NDTV
summary:
First Severe Human Infection of Bird Flu Reported in the US

Publication Date: Wednesday

Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

A patient in Louisiana has been hospitalized with a severe infection of avian influenza, marking the first serious human case in the United States during the current 2024 outbreak, according to the CDC.

  • The total number of avian influenza infections in the US has reached 61 during this outbreak.
  • The patient had exposure to sick and dead birds in backyard flocks.
  • The H5N1 virus belonged to the D1.1 genotype, recently detected in US wild birds and poultry.
  • No evidence suggests human-to-human transmission of the virus.
  • CDC estimates the risk to the general public as low despite these cases.
This case underscores that, in addition to affected commercial poultry and dairy operations, wild birds and backyard flocks also can be a source of exposure.

Concerns are growing about the virus's adaptability and its potential for cross-species transmission, especially given that the outbreak was first reported in March.
newTitle: First Severe Human Infection of Bird Flu Reported in the US

title: Weight loss drugs could help end obesity but risks remain, says WHO - Deccan Herald
summary:
Weight loss drugs could help end obesity but risks remain, says WHO

Published: 18 December 2024, Source: WHO

A new class of weight loss drugs from Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly may transform the fight against obesity, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, the WHO warns of potential risks if health systems fail to plan adequately for their implementation.

  • The WHO claims the new GLP-1 receptor agonists could significantly impact obesity treatment.
  • Concerns exist that reliance on medications alone could diminish attention to comprehensive health strategies.
  • Over a billion people are obese globally, with 5 million obesity-related deaths reported in 2019.
  • The WHO advocates for viewing obesity as a chronic disease necessitating multi-faceted treatment approaches.
  • The agency is developing guidelines for equitable drug distribution and considering their inclusion in its essential medicines list in 2025.
“Medication in isolation will not be enough to address the obesity crisis.” - WHO Chief Scientist Jeremy Farrar

This opinion piece emphasizes the need for a holistic approach that combines lifestyle interventions with new medications to effectively combat obesity worldwide.
newTitle: Weight Loss Drugs Could Help Combat Obesity, Says WHO

title: 8 benefits of eating 2 dried apricots every morning - The Times of India
summary:
8 Benefits of Eating 2 Dried Apricots Every Morning

Publication Date: Dec 18, 2024 | Source: Times of India

This article highlights the health advantages of incorporating two dried apricots into your morning routine, detailing eight specific benefits.

  • Dried apricots promote digestive health by containing natural fiber.
  • They boost skin health with vitamins and antioxidants.
  • They provide a light, filling breakfast alternative.
  • Potassium in dried apricots aids in maintaining heart health.
  • They contribute to improved vision thanks to beta-carotene.
  • Dried apricots can enhance energy levels due to natural sugars and minerals.
  • They strengthen bones with calcium and magnesium.
  • They serve as a remedy for iron deficiency, supporting red blood cell production.
“Adding small, healthy habits to daily routine can have a big impact on overall well-being.” - Aadya Jha

Incorporating two dried apricots each morning provides numerous health benefits, supporting digestion, heart health, and overall wellness.
newTitle: 8 Benefits of Eating 2 Dried Apricots Every Morning

title: United States reports first severe case of bird flu in human, says CDC - WION
summary:
First Severe Bird Flu Case in Humans in the US Reported by CDC

Date: December 18, 2023 | Source: CDC

The CDC has confirmed the first severe case of bird flu in a human in the United States. A patient in Louisiana was hospitalized after being exposed to sick and dead birds.

  • The case was confirmed on December 13, 2023.
  • The patient was exposed to backyard flocks of birds.
  • There have been 61 reported cases in the current outbreak affecting birds and poultry in the US.
  • No human-to-human transmission has been reported.
  • The CDC maintains that the risk to the general public is low.
"...in addition to affected commercial poultry and dairy operations, wild birds and backyard flocks also can be a source of exposure." - CDC

Despite this being the first severe case reported in the US, the CDC reassures that the overall risk remains low for the general public.
newTitle: First Severe Bird Flu Case in Humans in the US Reported by CDC

Myth busted? Vitamin D won't prevent falls or fractures, here's what a new study says - The Times of India
Chronic Inflammation Driven by Diet May Contribute to Colorectal Cancer, Study Finds - Pharmacy Times
summary:
Chronic Inflammation Driven by Diet May Contribute to Colorectal Cancer, Study Finds

Published on: December 10, 2024 | Source: Gut

Researchers have discovered a potential link between ultra-processed foods and an increased risk of colorectal cancer (CRC), suggesting that chronic inflammation from such diets encourages tumor growth.

  • The study published in Gut indicates that a Western diet high in ultra-processed foods contributes to tumor growth through inflammation.
  • CRC rates are rising, particularly among individuals under 50; this demographic is seeing a 13% increase in cancer cases over the past decade.
  • Dr. Timothy Yeatman highlights that unhealthy diets lead to increased inflammation, impacting the body’s healing ability.
  • The investigation showed an imbalance of pro-inflammatory lipid mediators in CRC affected tissue.
  • Prevention through a balanced diet may significantly reduce CRC risks.
“It is well known that patients with unhealthy diets have increased inflammation in their bodies.” - Dr. Timothy Yeatman

This study emphasizes the importance of diet in cancer prevention and encourages further exploration into the role of nutrition in health outcomes.
newTitle: Chronic Inflammation Driven by Diet May Contribute to Colorectal Cancer, Study Finds

title: Scientists uncovers a protein that helps cancer cells hide: All about the breakthrough discovery - The Times of India
Russia Launches Free Cancer Vaccine: Free Distribution To Begin In 2025 - Oneindia
summary:
Russia Launches Free Cancer Vaccine: Free Distribution To Begin In 2025

Published: Wednesday, December 18, 2024, 20:53 [IST] Source: OneIndia News

In a groundbreaking announcement, Russia has revealed the development of an mRNA cancer vaccine designed to treat patients. The vaccine will be made available starting in early 2025 and will be distributed free of charge to Russian citizens.

  • The mRNA cancer vaccine intends to treat existing cancers.
  • Each dose costs around 300,000 rubles (approximately USD 2,869) to the government.
  • The vaccine is customized for each patient using advanced AI techniques.
  • In 2022, Russia had over 635,000 cancer cases recorded.
  • This initiative is part of a larger global effort to develop personalized cancer vaccines.
“As 2025 approaches, the world will closely watch how this initiative unfolds, offering hope to millions in Russia...”

The introduction of this free cancer vaccine represents a significant step forward in cancer treatment, aiming to alleviate the burden of cancer and advance personalized medicine in Russia.
newTitle: Russia Launches Free Cancer Vaccine: Free Distribution To Begin In 2025

title: Science Reveals How Light Exercise Enhances Mental Agility - SciTechDaily
Does antioxidant-rich diet make your brain younger? Study explains how - The Times of India
summary:
Does Antioxidant-Rich Diet Make Your Brain Younger? Study Explains How

Date: October 2023
Source: Medical News Today

Recent research from the University of Kentucky reveals that an antioxidant-rich diet may help lower iron buildup in the brain, thereby reducing the risk of cognitive issues and promoting brain health.

  • A diet high in antioxidants can reduce the risk of numerous diseases.
  • Antioxidants help to scavenge free radicals from body cells.
  • The study involved 72 older adults and measured brain iron levels using advanced MRI techniques.
  • Increased brain iron levels were linked to cognitive decline in specific memory and executive function tasks.
  • Foods high in antioxidants include various fruits, vegetables, nuts, and whole grains.
“Iron is a vital element for brain health, playing a key role in essential cellular functions.” – Valentinos Zachariou, PhD

In conclusion, adopting an antioxidant-rich diet not only promotes physical health but may also lead to improved cognitive functionality and healthier aging.
newTitle: Does an Antioxidant-Rich Diet Make Your Brain Younger? Study Insights

summary:
Best and Worst Ways of Using Cooking Oil for Cutting Cancer Risk

Publication Date: Not specified; Source: Not specified.

This article explores the impact of different cooking oils on cancer risk, discussing which types are beneficial and which should be avoided.

  • Different types of cooking oils affect cancer risk differently.
  • Healthy oils can potentially lower the risk of cancer.
  • Certain oils may increase cancer risk when heated.
"Using oils wisely can make a significant difference in health outcomes related to cancer."

In conclusion, understanding the properties of cooking oils can help individuals make informed dietary choices that could lower their cancer risk.

title: Blood Test Identifies Early Brain Changes Linked to Dementia Risk - Inside Precision Medicine
summary:
Blood Test Identifies Early Brain Changes Linked to Dementia Risk

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Inside Precision Medicine

Researchers at UCLA have discovered a new blood-based biomarker that could detect early brain changes associated with cognitive impairment and dementia. The study indicates that elevated levels of placental growth factor in the blood may signal vascular brain injury before significant cognitive decline occurs.

  • The research focuses on cerebral small vessel disease, a major contributor to cognitive decline and dementia.
  • Elevated placental growth factor (PlGF) levels correlate with vascular permeability and cognitive performance.
  • A diverse group of participants aged 55 and older was analyzed to explore the associations between PlGF levels and cognitive decline.
  • This blood test presents a cost-effective alternative to MRI for early detection of vascular brain injury.
“As a biomarker for cerebral small vessel disease and the vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID), PlGF could be used as a cost-effective screening tool for identifying patients at risk.” - Kyle Kern, MD

The findings emphasize the need for further studies to confirm the relationships between PlGF, brain injury, and cognitive decline. If successful, this blood test could dramatically improve early dementia screening and intervention efforts.
newTitle: Blood Test Identifies Early Brain Changes Linked to Dementia Risk

title: Kerala struggles with a surge in mumps cases as infections cross 70,000 this year - The Week
summary:
Kerala Faces Major Mumps Outbreak with Over 70,000 Cases Reported

Date: 2023
Source: Local Health Department Reports

The state of Kerala is experiencing a significant surge in mumps cases, with over 70,000 reported this year, a dramatic increase from 2,324 cases in 2023. Health officials are concerned about the rising numbers as many individuals seek alternative medical treatments instead of conventional methods.

  • Malappuram and Kannur are severely affected, with 13,643 and 12,800 reported cases, respectively.
  • Schools have closed and mask mandates are in effect to curb the spread.
  • Mumps is a viral illness leading to swollen salivary glands and is highly contagious.
  • Complications of mumps can be severe, especially in unvaccinated individuals.
  • Health officials attribute the outbreak to a lack of vaccinations among children.
“The only way to stop the rise of mumps is to either bring back the MMR vaccine or properly inform people that it is accessible in private hospitals.” - Dr. Aneseya P. Varghese

Despite no reported deaths, health authorities are urging for immediate action to address this urgent public health issue.
newTitle: Kerala Faces Major Mumps Outbreak with Over 70,000 Cases Reported

title: Recap 2024: How pathogens emerged in new territories and forms this year - Down To Earth Magazine
summary:
Recap 2024: How Pathogens Emerged in New Territories and Forms This Year

Publication Date: 2024
Source: Down To Earth

As threats of new global pandemics loom due to climate change, 2024 has seen the emergence of various pathogens in new regions and forms, raising concerns over potential outbreaks.

  • Experts warn that a new pandemic could arise by 2030 due to zoonotic diseases.
  • The avian influenza strain H5N1 was reported to have killed penguins in the sub-Antarctic for the first time in January 2024.
  • COVID-19 cases saw a global rise, with a new variant, XEC, identified in multiple countries.
  • A mysterious disease resulted in numerous deaths in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
  • A new cholera strain resistant to multiple antibiotics emerged from Yemen, spreading to France.
“More than 80 percent of experts rated expanding or changing range due to climate change as factors that could make outbreaks more frequent or severe.”

The emergence of pathogens and the evolving nature of existing viruses highlight ongoing challenges in global health and the need for proactive measures to anticipate and respond to future outbreaks.
newTitle: Recap 2024: How Pathogens Emerged in New Territories and Forms This Year

title: Polio this week as of 18 December 2024 - ReliefWeb
summary:
Polio Update: Key Developments as of December 18, 2024

Date: 18 Dec 2024
Source: World Health Organization

This article outlines the latest updates on polio eradication efforts as of December 18, 2024, highlighting significant findings from various global health meetings and reports.

  • The WHO Executive Board will discuss polio eradication strategies in February 2025.
  • Recent recommendations from the SAGE emphasize the importance of concurrent use of IPV and nOPV2 in outbreak response vaccination campaigns.
  • Environmental samples from the UK, Finland, and Germany have indicated the presence of cVDPV2, prompting ongoing investigations by health authorities.
The report provides an update on work towards fully implementing and financing the Polio Eradication Strategy.

The article concludes by stressing the continuous surveillance and monitoring efforts by public health authorities in affected regions, ensuring high vaccination coverage remains a priority.
newTitle: Polio Update: Key Developments as of December 18, 2024

title: Two US men use bat poop to cultivate cannabis, succumb to death - Deccan Herald
summary:
Two US Men Use Bat Poop to Cultivate Cannabis, Succumb to Death

Date: 18 December 2024, Source: Open Forum Infectious Diseases

In a shocking incident, two men from Rochester, New York, died after inhaling spores from bat feces, known as guano, which they planned to use as fertilizer for cannabis cultivation.

  • The men developed severe symptoms leading to respiratory failure due to histoplasmosis.
  • This rare lung infection is caused by the Histoplasma capsulatum fungus found in bat droppings.
  • The incident highlights the health risks associated with using bat guano in cannabis cultivation.
“Exposure to bat guano among cannabis growers appears to be a recent trend that can lead to histoplasmosis cases and outbreaks.”

The incident underscores the need for awareness and testing of commercial fertilizers containing bat guano to prevent similar tragedies in the future.
newTitle: Two US Men Die from Bat Guano-Linked Lung Infection

title: Microplastics in the air may be leading to lung and colon cancers - Medical Xpress
Study Reveals Flu Virus Remains Infectious in Refrigerated Raw Milk - Morning Ag Clips -
summary:
Study Reveals Flu Virus Remains Infectious in Refrigerated Raw Milk

Publication Date: December 12, 2023 | Source: Stanford University via EurekAlert!

This study highlights the risks associated with consuming raw milk, revealing that influenza virus can remain infectious in refrigerated raw milk for up to five days. As concerns about bird flu outbreaks in dairy cattle grow, the findings emphasize the importance of milk pasteurization.

  • Over 14 million Americans consume raw milk annually.
  • The flu virus H1N1 PR8 can remain infectious in raw milk for up to five days.
  • Flu virus RNA can be detected in raw milk for at least 57 days.
  • Pasteurization effectively destroys infectious influenza in milk.
  • Flu viruses infect over 40 million Americans each year, leading to over 50,000 deaths.
  • Recent cases of bird flu in cattle raise concerns about potential transmission through dairy products.
“The persistence of infectious influenza virus in raw milk for days raises concerns about potential transmission pathways.” – Mengyang Zhang

This research sheds light on food safety regarding raw milk consumption and emphasizes the need for improved monitoring systems as avian influenza continues to spread among livestock.
newTitle: Study Reveals Flu Virus Remains Infectious in Refrigerated Raw Milk

title: Colon cancer: Higher biological age linked to increased risk of polyps - Medical News Today
summary:
Colon cancer: Measuring ‘biological age’ may help predict who's at risk for polyps

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Medical News Today

This article discusses new research indicating that biological age, reflecting an individual’s physiological condition, may be a key predictor of the risk for developing colon polyps, which are precursors to colorectal cancer.

  • Research from the Sylvester Comprehensive Cancer Center suggests faster biological aging correlates with increased polyp risk.
  • For every year of accelerated biological aging, the risk of developing polyps increases by 16%.
  • These findings may lead to earlier screenings for those with accelerated biological ages.
“Biological aging is a measure of your body’s age based on changes in DNA.”
— Shria Kumar, MD, MSCE

Colorectal cancer, particularly among individuals under 50, is rising, emphasizing the need for risk stratification in screenings. Future studies should validate the findings to enhance preventive strategies.
newTitle: Colon Cancer Risk: Biological Age May Indicate Vulnerability to Polyps
